activityTypes.name: Accept
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor accepts the object. The target property can be used in certain circumstances to indicate the context into which the object has been accepted.

object.summary: Sally accepted an invitation to a party
Sally accepted Joe into the club

activityTypes.name: TentativeAccept
activityTypes.notes: A specialization of Accept indicating that the acceptance is tentative.

object.summary: Sally tentatively accepted an invitation to a party

activityTypes.name: Add
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has added the object to the target. If the target property is not explicitly specified, the target would need to be determined implicitly by context. The origin can be used to identify the context from which the object originated.

object.summary: Sally added a picture of her cat to her cat picture collection

activityTypes.name: Arrive
activityTypes.notes: An IntransitiveActivity that indicates that the actor has arrived at the location. The origin can be used to identify the context from which the actor originated. The target typically has no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: Create
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has created the object.

activityTypes.name: Delete
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has deleted the object. If specified, the origin indicates the context from which the object was deleted.

activityTypes.name: Follow
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is "following" the object. Following is defined in the sense typically used within Social systems in which the actor is interested in any activity performed by or on the object. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: Ignore
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is ignoring the object. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: Join
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has joined the object. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: Leave
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has left the object. The target and origin typically have no meaning.

activityTypes.name: Like
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor likes, recommends or endorses the object. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: Offer
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is offering the object. If specified, the target indicates the entity to which the object is being offered.

activityTypes.name: Invite
activityTypes.notes: A specialization of Offer in which the actor is extending an invitation for the object to the target.

object.summary: Sally invited John and Lisa to a party

activityTypes.name: Reject
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is rejecting the object. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

object.summary: Sally rejected an invitation to a party

activityTypes.name: TentativeReject
activityTypes.notes: A specialization of Reject in which the rejection is considered tentative.

object.summary: Sally tentatively rejected an invitation to a party

activityTypes.name: Remove
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is removing the object. If specified, the origin indicates the context from which the object is being removed.

object.summary: Sally removed a note from her notes folder
The moderator removed Sally from a group

activityTypes.name: Undo
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is undoing the object. In most cases, the object will be an Activity describing some previously performed action (for instance, a person may have previously "liked" an article but, for whatever reason, might choose to undo that like at some later point in time). The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

object.summary: Sally retracted her offer to John

activityTypes.name: Update
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has updated the object. Note, however, that this vocabulary does not define a mechanism for describing the actual set of modifications made to object. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: View
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has viewed the object.

object.name: What You Should Know About Activity Streams

activityTypes.name: Listen
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has listened to the object.

object.summary: Sally listened to a piece of music

activityTypes.name: Read
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has read the object.

activityTypes.name: Move
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor has moved object from origin to target. If the origin or target are not specified, either can be determined by context.

object.summary: Sally moved a post from List A to List B

activityTypes.name: Travel
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is traveling to target from origin. Travel is an IntransitiveObject whose actor specifies the direct object. If the target or origin are not specified, either can be determined by context.

activityTypes.name: Announce
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is calling the target's attention the object. The origin typically has no defined meaning.

object.summary: Sally announced that she had arrived at work

activityTypes.name: Block
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is blocking the object. Blocking is a stronger form of Ignore. The typical use is to support social systems that allow one user to block activities or content of other users. The target and origin typically have no defined meaning.

activityTypes.name: Flag
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor is "flagging" the object. Flagging is defined in the sense common to many social platforms as reporting content as being inappropriate for any number of reasons.

activityTypes.name: Dislike
activityTypes.notes: Indicates that the actor dislikes the object.

activityTypes.name: Question
activityTypes.notes: Represents a question being asked. Question objects are an extension of IntransitiveActivity. That is, the Question object is an Activity, but the direct object is the question itself and therefore it would not contain an object property. Either of the anyOf and oneOf properties MAY be used to express possible answers, but a Question object MUST NOT have both properties.

properties.name: id
properties.notes: Provides the globally unique identifier for an Object or Link.

properties.name: type
properties.notes: Identifies the Object or Link type. Multiple values may be specified.

properties.name: actor
properties.notes: Describes one or more entities that either performed or are expected to perform the activity. Any single activity can have multiple actors. The actor MAY be specified using an indirect Link.

object.summary: Sally and Joe offered the Foo object

properties.name: attachment
properties.notes: Identifies a resource attached or related to an object that potentially requires special handling. The intent is to provide a model that is at least semantically similar to attachments in email.

attachment.content: This is what he looks like.

properties.name: attributedTo
properties.notes: Identifies one or more entities to which this object is attributed. The attributed entities might not be Actors. For instance, an object might be attributed to the completion of another activity.

properties.name: audience
properties.notes: Identifies one or more entities that represent the total population of entities for which the object can considered to be relevant.

object.name: Holiday announcement
object.content: Thursday will be a company-wide holiday. Enjoy your day off!

properties.name: bcc
properties.notes: Identifies one or more Objects that are part of the private secondary audience of this Object.

object.summary: Sally offered a post to John

properties.name: bto
properties.notes: Identifies an Object that is part of the private primary audience of this Object.

object.summary: Sally offered a post to John

properties.name: cc
properties.notes: Identifies an Object that is part of the public secondary audience of this Object.

object.summary: Sally offered a post to John

properties.name: context
properties.notes: Identifies the context within which the object exists or an activity was performed. The notion of "context" used is intentionally vague. The intended function is to serve as a means of grouping objects and activities that share a common originating context or purpose. An example could be all activities relating to a common project or event.

properties.name: current
properties.notes: In a paged Collection, indicates the page that contains the most recently updated member items.

properties.name: first
properties.notes: In a paged Collection, indicates the furthest preceeding page of items in the collection.

properties.name: generator
properties.notes: Identifies the entity (e.g. an application) that generated the object.

properties.name: icon
properties.notes: Indicates an entity that describes an icon for this object. The image should have an aspect ratio of one (horizontal) to one (vertical) and should be suitable for presentation at a small size.

properties.name: image
properties.notes: Indicates an entity that describes an image for this object. Unlike the icon property, there are no aspect ratio or display size limitations assumed.

properties.name: inReplyTo
properties.notes: Indicates one or more entities for which this object is considered a response.

properties.name: instrument
properties.notes: Identifies one or more objects used (or to be used) in the completion of an Activity.

object.summary: Sally listened to a piece of music on the Acme Music Service

properties.name: last
properties.notes: In a paged Collection, indicates the furthest proceeding page of the collection.

properties.name: location
properties.notes: Indicates one or more physical or logical locations associated with the object.

location.name: Over the Arabian Sea, east of Socotra Island Nature Sanctuary

properties.name: items
properties.notes: Identifies the items contained in a collection. The items might be ordered or unordered.

properties.name: oneOf
properties.notes: Identifies an exclusive option for a Question. Use of oneOf implies that the Question can have only a single answer. To indicate that a Question can have multiple answers, use anyOf.

properties.name: anyOf
properties.notes: Identifies an inclusive option for a Question. Use of anyOf implies that the Question can have multiple answers. To indicate that a Question can have only one answer, use oneOf.

properties.name: closed
properties.notes: Indicates that a question has been closed, and answers are no longer accepted.

properties.name: origin
properties.notes: Describes an indirect object of the activity from which the activity is directed. The precise meaning of the origin is the object of the English preposition "from". For instance, in the activity "John moved an item to List B from List A", the origin of the activity is "List A".

object.summary: Sally moved a post from List A to List B

properties.name: next
properties.notes: In a paged Collection, indicates the next page of items.

properties.name: object
properties.notes: When used within an Activity, describes the direct object of the activity. For instance, in the activity "John added a movie to his wishlist", the object of the activity is the movie added. When used within a Relationship describes the entity to which the subject is related.

properties.name: prev
properties.notes: In a paged Collection, identifies the previous page of items.

properties.name: preview
properties.notes: Identifies an entity that provides a preview of this object.

properties.name: result
properties.notes: Describes the result of the activity. For instance, if a particular action results in the creation of a new resource, the result property can be used to describe that new resource.

object.summary: Sally checked that her flight was on time

properties.name: replies
properties.notes: Identifies a Collection containing objects considered to be responses to this object.

items.content: I am glad to hear it.

properties.name: tag
properties.notes: One or more "tags" that have been associated with an objects. A tag can be any kind of Object. The key difference between attachment and tag is that the former implies association by inclusion, while the latter implies associated by reference.

properties.name: target
properties.notes: Describes the indirect object, or target, of the activity. The precise meaning of the target is largely dependent on the type of action being described but will often be the object of the English preposition "to". For instance, in the activity "John added a movie to his wishlist", the target of the activity is John's wishlist. An activity can have more than one target.

object.summary: Sally offered the post to John
Sally offered the post to John

properties.name: to
properties.notes: Identifies an entity considered to be part of the public primary audience of an Object

object.summary: Sally offered the post to John

properties.name: url
properties.notes: Identifies one or more links to representations of the object

properties.name: accuracy
properties.notes: Indicates the accuracy of position coordinates on a Place objects. Expressed in properties of percentage. e.g. "94.0" means "94.0% accurate".

object.name: Liu Gu Lu Cun, Pingdu, Qingdao, Shandong, China

properties.name: altitude
properties.notes: Indicates the altitude of a place. The measurement units is indicated using the units property. If units is not specified, the default is assumed to be "m" indicating meters.

properties.name: content
properties.notes: The content or textual representation of the Object encoded as a JSON string. By default, the value of content is HTML. The mediaType property can be used in the object to indicate a different content type. The content MAY be expressed using multiple language-tagged values.

object.content:
## A simple note
A simple markdown `note`

properties.name: name
properties.notes: A simple, human-readable, plain-text name for the object. HTML markup MUST NOT be included. The name MAY be expressed using multiple language-tagged values.

properties.name: duration
properties.notes: When the object describes a time-bound resource, such as an audio or video, a meeting, etc, the duration property indicates the object's approximate duration. The value MUST be expressed as an xsd:duration as defined by [ xmlschema11-2], section 3.3.6 (e.g. a period of 5 seconds is represented as "PT5S").

properties.name: height
properties.notes: On a Link, specifies a hint as to the rendering height in device-independent pixels of the linked resource.

properties.name: href
properties.notes: The target resource pointed to by a Link.

properties.name: hreflang
properties.notes: Hints as to the language used by the target resource. Value MUST be a [BCP47] Language-Tag.

properties.name: partOf
properties.notes: Identifies the Collection to which a CollectionPage objects items belong.

properties.name: latitude
properties.notes: The latitude of a place

properties.name: longitude
properties.notes: The longitude of a place

properties.name: mediaType
properties.notes: When used on a Link, identifies the MIME media type of the referenced resource. When used on an Object, identifies the MIME media type of the value of the content property. If not specified, the content property is assumed to contain text/html content.

properties.name: endTime
properties.notes: The date and time describing the actual or expected ending time of the object. When used with an Activity object, for instance, the endTime property specifies the moment the activity concluded or is expected to conclude.

properties.name: published
properties.notes: The date and time at which the object was published

properties.name: startTime
properties.notes: The date and time describing the actual or expected starting time of the object. When used with an Activity object, for instance, the startTime property specifies the moment the activity began or is scheduled to begin.

properties.name: radius
properties.notes: The radius from the given latitude and longitude for a Place. The units is expressed by the units property. If units is not specified, the default is assumed to be "m" indicating "meters".

properties.name: rel
properties.notes: A link relation associated with a Link. The value MUST conform to both the [HTML5] and [RFC5988] "link relation" definitions. In the [HTML5], any string not containing the "space" U+0020, "tab" (U+0009), "LF" (U+000A), "FF" (U+000C), "CR" (U+000D) or "," (U+002C) characters can be used as a valid link relation.

properties.name: startIndex
properties.notes: A non-negative integer value identifying the relative position within the logical view of a strictly ordered collection.

properties.name: summary
properties.notes: A natural language summarization of the object encoded as HTML. Multiple language tagged summaries MAY be provided.

properties.name: totalItems
properties.notes: A non-negative integer specifying the total number of objects contained by the logical view of the collection. This number might not reflect the actual number of items serialized within the Collection object instance.

properties.name: units
properties.notes: Specifies the measurement units for the radius and altitude properties on a Place object. If not specified, the default is assumed to be "m" for "meters".

properties.name: updated
properties.notes: The date and time at which the object was updated

object.name: Cranberry Sauce Idea
object.content: Mush it up so it does not have the same shape as the can.

properties.name: width
properties.notes: On a Link, specifies a hint as to the rendering width in device-independent pixels of the linked resource.

properties.name: subject
properties.notes: On a Relationship object, the subject property identifies one of the connected individuals. For instance, for a Relationship object describing "John is related to Sally", subject would refer to John.

object.summary: Sally is an acquaintance of John's

properties.name: relationship
properties.notes: On a Relationship object, the relationship property identifies the kind of relationship that exists between subject and object.

object.summary: Sally is an acquaintance of John's

properties.name: describes
properties.notes: On a Profile object, the describes property identifies the object described by the Profile.

properties.name: formerType
properties.notes: On a Tombstone object, the formerType property identifies the type of the object that was deleted.

properties.name: deleted
properties.notes: On a Tombstone object, the deleted property is a timestamp for when the object was deleted.
